Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 08:36AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: This is exactly what they found in mine.....clustered calcifications that turned out to be cancerous.My GYN told me I had caught it early..but then I go to the surgeon and she feels a lump and skin thickening under my arm and says it has spread to there. I guess I won't know that for sure until Weds when I go back to the oncologist. After having a biopsy, a port put in for chemo, and let's see, a muga scan, ct scan, bone scan, pet scan, mri, the next plan of action is to start chemo first..I then undergo a lumpectomy and I assume the thyroid glands affected taken out if that's indeed the case, then radiation, then 5 yrs on a pill that makes my body cease creating hormone which is what is feeding this cancer. Mine was hormone receptive. It's a Stage 2. And I'm not entirely sure that is true as no tests were done to determine if under my arm is cancerous or not. My calcifications were not considered a large area, but one little spot had escaped the cluster........ Now after saying that, please be mindful that you will hear 2 million different things on the net. You came here, to the right place, I too was scared after reading all that stuff....but there are women on here who have been through all of this, well I call them angels. They are very extremely knowledgable and are sooooooo comforting.......so just keep reading posts on here, the more you read, the more  you learn..........And trust in the Lord, keep your faith........ Prayers going out for you that it is indeed B9. Deb
Posts.Title: Large Coarse Clusterred Clacifications ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 08:45AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: 39mom, I am Stage III, or was...had 4 rounds of every other week A/C, 12 weekly taxols, before I had even finished the taxol, the tumors were gone........I've had surgery, she took out 5 nodes, only one had a minuscule bit of cancer in it, no cancer showed up in the breast. I have to still go through radiation, but as of now, am NED.........free of cancer.......so have hope! Hugs Deb

Posts.Title: Insurance company will not cover my MRI blas dlb823

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 08:45AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Yeah I did hear that...but I had no problem healing after my lumpectomy and node dissection...thing is, stress causes hormones to release. If her cancer is like mine, and is hormone positive, releasing hormones into your body is not a good thing. That is why he told me to not try to quit during chemo. Of course now that I only have rads left, he's all over me to quit! LOL
Posts.Title: ALCOHOL / SMOKING - during chemo!!! HELP!!! TravisC bwbly

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 08:34AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: It may come as a shock to you but I was told to NOT stop smoking during chemo...my onc told me he didn't want me stressed at all during chemo. He merely said to cut down. As for alcohol, even though I don't drink, they advised me not to... Deb

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 07:30PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Brian and Snowflake.   I am 30 miles east of Cincinnati in :Loveland...I go to Dr. Robert Cody for my oncologist. Cincinnati Magazine wrote him up as being one of the Top 5 in Cincy...He has an office in Hyde Park which is where I go but I believe there are other locations also. As for a Surgeon, I go to Karen Columbus down on Red Bank Road as soon as you turn off of Madison Road, I did alot of research and found out she was one of the Best in the Area.  Dr. Cody and his Staff are awesome people, he's very knowledgeable and very nice, easy to talk to and he spends time with you. Karen is a Gem...in fact I'm going to see her on the 6th to find out when my surgery is. (Have already had chemo). Very nice and she too spends time with you and is easy to talk to. Hope this helps somewhat! Hugs and Prayers Deb

Posts.Title: Tanning after Radiation Jeanne_D Jeanne_D

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 04:40AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: I enjoy tanning as I have several bad disks in my back along with bad knee's, that heat feels so good on those parts....of course I haven't been since last Oct when I was diagnosed but I have full intentions of going back. I tanned for oever 2 yrs and never once got a suspicious mark or anything else. I didn't go everyday, and I don't intend on going everyday when I go back. I just like the heat on my bones and a little color. Deb
Posts.Title: Tanning after Radiation Jeanne_D Jeanne_D

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 05:27AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Red meat causes cancer, alcohol causes cancer, the air we breathe causes cancer...everytime you step out the door, you're exposing yourself to cancer....tanning is no more of a risk then any of the others I've mentioned...there are even cancer causing chemicals in your water. So, should we stop eating, breathing, drinking water, stop doing everything? I didn't go thru 16 chemo treatments, surgery and the rads I'm starting tomorrow for nothing. I did it to live. And i plan on enjoying life. If it's meant for me to get cancer again, I will get it and nothing will stop that. For that matter, I could step outside tomorrow, cross the street and get killed by a car, should I stay in my house? I believe in being cautious, but I rather doubt going tanning a couple of times a week is going to kill me.
Posts.Title: Tanning after Radiation Jeanne_D Jeanne_D

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 05:40AM - edited Jun 9, 2009 05:41AM by Deb-from-Ohio Wish I could say that...I still have 6 weeks of radiation starting tomorrow and I'm already petrified of it coming back...Let's just say my luck isn't the best in the world.... I had to edit this to addl, but I'm not going to live in fear the rest of my life of what the consequences are of things I eat, do, etc......
Posts.Title: Tanning after Radiation Jeanne_D Jeanne_D

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 10:06PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Tricia, it's different for each person so really hard to tell you what to expect....I myself had a rough time on it......I did a treatment every other week for 4 treatments......but there are women on here who it didn't bother and went to work on it......the best tip I can give you is this......Drink all the water you can the day before treatment, the day of and the next few days afterwards.....you have to flush it out of your system.....without drinking plenty of water, after being there myself I can guarantee you that you will end up at the ER suffering from dehydration.......Not trying to scare you, just a very good tip as everyone else will tell you also.......... Luv, hugs and prayers Deb
Posts.Title: AC Triciaski Triciaski

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 09:08PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Nissy, sorry you had to join the club no one wants to join...but since you're here, take a deep breath and don't go scaring yourself by reading some of the posts on here...Like I did..LOL...this is beatable I'm living proof........and ignore the stats on the web, most are outdated garbage..Get your plan of action from your onc and move on with it..it's all doable. I'm 53 and if this old lady can do it, so can everyone!  Stick around, I've been on here almost a year and have not found one person who was not loving and supporting, all a bunch of great strong women who are willing to help! Hugs and Prayers Deb

Posts.Title: How soon after surgery? nanabolini carollynn79

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 09:13PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Diva, back in Oct of last year I was diagnosed Stage IIIA. Invasive and DCIS. My tumor was 3cm.  I don't know how big the area of DCIS was. I also had a smaller lump under my arm and lymph node invasion. I was started on chemo first, I did 4 every week treatments of A/C...and after that 12 weekly taxol...by the time I was done with chemo, they couldn't find any of the lumps. I had a catscan, when I went into get the results my onc asked me how it felt to be cancer free...of course I still had to have the lumpectomy and node dissection, they took out 5 nodes and only one node showed a miniscule bit of cancer. I am now going through radiation to make sure none of the sneaky cancer cells are still in there that are too small to show up on the catscan..but as for now, I am dancing with NED.......meaning no evidence of disease...so the chemo can and does work Great! Hugs
Posts.Title: Hope Seems Fleeting sutherndiva nene2059

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 06:04PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Thanks gang for all the good advice,,,,they told me they would put an iv in for the CT scan and just leave it in for the MRI......I plan on asking for someone who knows what they're doing, the only thing I'm worried about is laying on this port.....it still hurts alot and is very tender......Just had it put in on Wednesday.......I know I will get someone more experienced, my hubby has a temper......and he knew how devastated the other day I was and he's definitely still upset about it. So I have a feeling that they are going to get quite an earful when we go in........and this isn't a small hospital either....it's one of the major hospitals in our area, still can't believe it. Of course this is the same hospital where my Dad was with liver cancer with about a week to live and they told us since they weren't treating him, (he refused treatment, was tired and wanted to be with Mom) that we had to move him as soon as possible......pretty heartless...... Hugs & prayers and Thank you all so much, you people are wonderful on here.......it's so awesome to be able to talk to people who truly understand what I'm going through...... Love Deb
Posts.Title: I broke down today Deb-from-Ohio Harley44

I just love days when they go right!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! One more test to go on Thursday, a PET scan, I know I will need an IV there, but they're doing it at a different place, then am done with all these tests!! Well for awhile anyway! Posts.Title: I broke down today Deb-from-Ohio Harley44

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 12:46PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Hi Penny, yeah I know they have their job to do.....and I know they have certain things they have to do, but I had told his lady prior to her even starting the IV that it would be better in the hands as my veins do roll..she replied with, well we only use the hands as a last resort.......A young nurse had told me to tell people that in the future so it would be easier...Her giving me two pieces of guaze to put on the port area for padding didn't help, nor did it help her popularity any when I left she told me, well this is a confusing, nervewracking time for you, like it was my condition that hurt me, not her.....I believe it was a combo of things that day, my nerves were bad that day ( I also forgot to say that I had a hysterectomy 10 yrs ago and when I found out about the BC, was told to stop taking my hormone pills immediately, which makes things worse), then the mix up with the MRI appt, then the guy in the muga scan having to shoot me twice with the radioactive crud, by the time I got into the MRI room, I had just had enough.......I was ready to scream. Not to mention since this whole thing started, everything I have had done has been painful, my biopsy, the doc didn't get my breast numbed correctly and I came up off the table, it hurt so badly...this port is still very painful...it's just been one streak of bad luck after another. (Yup I would love some cheese wtih my whine! LOL)  But I do understand where you're coming from.....I know Monday, I will be taking a whole xanax before I go! LOL Deb
Posts.Title: I broke down today Deb-from-Ohio Harley44

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 06:25AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Thanks guys...my nerves were so bad yesterday I even had cold chills.....it's rescheduled for Monday along with the ct scan and bone scan although I still don't like the idea of laying on this port thing......my hubbys going with me then, I feel sorry for them cuz he's gonna chew someone a new you know what........ and Patrice, I hate this thing.......mine still hurts like all get out.......maybe i'm just too impatient....LOL Love,hugs and prayers Deb
Posts.Title: I broke down today Deb-from-Ohio Harley44

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 11:40AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Ladies sorry to butt in, but I just finished 4/AC and 12 weekly Taxol and I lived through it...it's not easy but like someone else said doable! And special note to those on Taxol, my head started getting peach fuzz on about the 7th infusion..........Also I noticed there is alot of crying going on, don't wait around for depression to get worse, get your oncologist to give you either ativan for nerves or xanax or even an antidepressant.........they will not think you're a drug addict..Most of the women on BC.org are on something for their nerves. And drink, drink and drink more water...You will find that the sooner  you flush it out of your system, the better off you are! Good Luck and Hugs Deb

Posts.Title: So scared AmyC just_mary

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 08:04AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Hi Sweetie, I was diagnosed on the 23rd of Oct, my daughters birthday and the day before mine....My first piece of advice is to talk to your doctors and get something for your nerves......I was like you, in a dream until realization set in.......At times I wonder if I'm still in a nightmare....but you did the right thing coming here, I have learned so much, and found so many wonderful, brave, kind hearted women.........2nd piece of advice, get a small notebook that  you can keep in your purse, write down what they tell you, write down any questions you may have for your doctor, it can also help you keep the dates right of tests, etc.......I to have IDC, invasive ductal carcinoma, (well along with something under my arm, they haven't figured that out yet) I was told it was the most common so I am going under the assumption it is the most treatable. 3rd and last piece of advice, post here! These women know alot!!!!!!! and you don't feel quite so alone that way.  As for having more kids, don't know. I had a hysterectomy so never asked bout that one.........talk to your doc about your concerns......... Keep us in touch Deb
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed RLS2713 LaurelS

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 01:10PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: I had my two German Shepherds and 2 cats around me during chemo and didn't bother me at all.......the older, bigger one in fact was like a nurse during the time I was down from A/C, he wouldn't leave my side......I did however use Purel after petting them to make sure......but that was it...... Luv, hugs and prayers Deb
Posts.Title: Chemo and dogs wiz2 kimbly

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 02:22AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: TwinMom...so sorry you're here.  I know the feeling about wanting your life back...and you will get it back, but I promise you that you will be a better person when this is all done..I was diagnosed in Oct of last year, I went through chemo first to shrink the tumors, after chemo, I had a 100% response. Cancer free, well worth losing my hair over. I still had to have a lumpectomy and node dissection and am currently going through radiation. But the SE's, the losing the hair was well worth it to live. And now I appreciate life more..I don't take things for granted, I have as much fun as i can. I love as much as I can. I don't stress over stupid things anymore. So see, you will have a different life when this is done, but a much better life. Just please, you and Jewlls and whoever else is new here, don't go reading stats on the web, most of them are so old and outdated...and the chemo threads? Well everyone reacts to that differently. So don't get scared! Good Luck and Hugs Deb

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 10:18PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: OMG how horrible to be treated like that! It's bad enough to have this $#%^$^! disease, but to have a nurse who is supposed to be compassionate treat you that way?  Your oncologist sounds about the same way. I just switched onc's a month ago because of one that treated me badly, I just refuse to put up with it, this is my life on the line, not theirs, I'm paying them. My new onc told me that I would be getting scans later on.....(I still have 11 weekly taxols to go)..........but since I'm getting my chemo first, then surgery, I believe he said it would be after the surgery. I would insist on the scans. Just remember, YOU'RE paying them......... Luv, hugs and prayers Deb

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 11:41PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: I've got two very large german shepherds and two cats...while I can't clean the litterbox (gee what a shame), I can do everything else, even when my WBC's are low from the chemo I still love on them and pet them, I just wash my hands afterwards and use Purex...there's nothing to fear about a dog getting you sick.. My bigger one, he weighs well over 150lbs, big,. white long hair, he was my chemo nurse when I was on A/C.  If I laid on the couch sick, he was laying on the floor next to me, if I sat up, he was right there next to me...dogs give you so much unconditional love, and I truly believe they worry also.... Deb

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 09:58AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Rye   Wait until you talk to your surgeon before making your mind up, they might just recommend a lumpectomy.  I had a 3cm tumor in my breast, IDC, stage III and lymph node involvement. I went through chemo first, by the time I finished, they could no longer find the lumps...so I had a lumpectomy and am currently going through radiation One word of advice, don't go reading alot of the posts here, they will scare you needlessly...not until you find out exacty what you're dealing with. Hugs and prayers Deb

Am ok, have 2 more treatments...two more weeks...fingernails are lifting off, have bandaids holding them on, get really tired , the normal after steroid crash, but bout it...eyes still watering but have peach fuzz on the head, so that's a plus. Have an appt on April 6th with my breast surgeon for an exam and to talk about what she's going to do, schedule surgery and all..my onc said she will probably order another MRI, am sure my ins. company will love that one. But still hanging in there, had to go on antidepressants, couldn't take it no more...Lexapro but they seem to be helping alot. Bout it...Where are you in treatment? How are you doing?
Posts.Title: Embracing the Bald BooBee Meadow

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 06:39PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Bridget, I tried once to quit cold turkey and my doctor chewed me out.......(regular doc) I'm 53 and have been smoking since I was 13....he said that was way to much stress on my body since I have smoked so long and have high blood pressure and I was lucky I didn't have a heart attack.........Said if I wanted to quit, either use something or to cut down gradually........I have enough on my plate right now with the cancer, I have 5 kids and something is always going on with them, and 17 grandkids......just too much stress right now......... Hugs Deb
Posts.Title: Smoking and no masectomy? Deb-from-Ohio anianiau

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 04:53PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Ellen, my first oncologist was that way about smoking....my daughter went with me the first time, even before she examined me, she found out we both smoked, she spent 5 mins yelling at us, and I do mean yelling, then told me I was wasting my time coming there......well after that she hated me.First A/C I didn't drink enuff water, had to go to the hospital once for liquids, and then down to the onc's lab for liquids......nothing was hurting, didn't ask for nothing......Second time I went to the hospital, the side of my neck had swelled up where the port is....called the onc's office, the onc on call told me to go to the hospital. So I go....er doc asks between 1 to 10 what is pain scale. Said a 2, maybe a 3. He asks if I wanted something for pain, told him a couple of advils...he says oh no, I have something better and shoots me full of morphine. He felt my neck, said it was swelled, ordered blood tests to check for clots and had to go back the next day for an ultrasound. They found nothing. He gave me a script for percocet. I had them filled cuz my hubby had an abcessed tooth. He took one, the rest are on top of my fridge, I hate pain pills. So next time I go to see the witch doc, she comes storming in, says I have been to the hospital twice and t hat I am just going to get pain pills, basically calling me a drug addict! I was so humilated. I explaned to her, first time I wasn't in pain, didn't ask for nothing for pain, she says the second time the ER doc had told that my neck wasn't swelled.....I asked her who was going to give someone morphine, order blood work, and an ultrasound if he didn't think there was something wrong? I told her the doc said it was and my hubby who was with me told her it was swelled.And that one of her fellow docs told me to go......told her I had the whole  bottle of percocet on the refridge...she didn't believe me.....so I switched docs........felt like suing her. My daughter even called her to assure her I didn't have a drug problem! She was very rude to my daughter and at the end said well I can't discuss your mothers case with you but I can tell you I feel she has a problem with pain pills.....I just couldn't believe it!  I have taken 20 vicodeine from back in October when I had my port installed and thats it, other  then xanax.....and I still have 4 of those left and they were prescribed in November!  The doc I have now is a really nice person and it's so nice to trust your doc....I love this guy! Luv Deb

Posts.Title: patient-doctor relationship: your thoughts and experiences paige-allyson KerryMac

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 10:20PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Hey Bridget    They did chemo on me first to shrink the tumor, as I said earlier or maybe I didn't in this message, after the 3rd A/C it had shrunk 90%......since then I've had one more A/C and go for my second taxol tomorrow, will have a total of 12 of those...It's also in my lymph nodes and there was a small tumor under my arm, but last time the doc couldn't barely find it........then I go in for a lumpectomy, then  radiation, then providing they don't find anymore cancer and I don't have to go back for more chemo, onto 5 yrs of arimidex......My B.S thinks she can get it all with a lumpectomy......although she says she can't do that masectomy since I smoke.....who knows.......my onc says don't be surprised if I do end up getting a masectomy...they're all confusing to me. I was just diagnosed Oct 23rd,on my daughters 30th birthday....had to call her and say Happy Birthday, I have cancer.......but I swear it feels as if it's been 20  yrs ago.....Guess will know more next time I see my oncologist.....right now I'm just seeing the mid level care people.....think I see him in two weeks........ Luv, hugs and prayers Deb
Posts.Title: Smoking and no masectomy? Deb-from-Ohio anianiau

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 01:42PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Makes no difference now as the tumor in my breast that was 3.5cm I think, now cannot be found for the second week by the same med level assistant, nor could she find the one under my arm....even she said today I should be a perfect lumpectomy.......which is good.......won't have to cut out as much! Lov Deb
Posts.Title: Smoking and no masectomy? Deb-from-Ohio anianiau

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 05:58PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: I have invasive ductal carcinoma too, one small clustered area, well a few did escape.........there is also a lump under my arm along with thickening of the skin which they haven't tested yet, but tell me it has probably spread to there.........I asked why she kept calling the calcifications a tumor, she told me (the oncologist) that they call it all a tumor. To them, anything with cancer in it is considered a tumor..... and yes.....my other breast hurts all the time.......but I think in my mind I am thinking every little pinch, ache, cramp, whatever as cancer now..........so my mind is more alert to any tiny little pain.....of course then too, that is the side they put the port on.....so that may be why that side hurts also...... Have they told you what the course of action will be? Feel free to private message me if you want, I don't know why but on here they have a limit of 5 posts per day for a 24 hr period which is really sad, You get diagnosed, you have so many questions, so many things pop into your mind.......... Hugs and prayers Deb

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 01:06PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Hey gal, what ljh58 told you is true, don't go lookin at statistics on the web, for the most part, they're Old and outdated.........Just hang in there hon..millions of us have gone through it, you can make it too! All the girls here have given you excellent advice. One more piece though and what I have done is to keep a notebook, in it I have my biopsy report, everything, tests I have done, even bills I've paid, insurance statements, basically everything. This way I can go back and look at a glance to find out what was done, when it was done, etc. Hugs and prayers!

Posts.Title: PET Results are In! webwriter apple

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 02:44PM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: Kerry.......I am stage III also, never considered it a poor prognosis......I have had 4 treatments of A/C which has shrunk my tumor 90%, well that was after the 3rd treatment..As for my nodes, they tell me I have cancer there also but until surgery don't know of how many are affected....I am now on 12 weekly sessions of Taxol, then I will have a lumpectomy, then radiation.....My onc says I am doing quite well .....so keep the hope up honey........the chemo is doable.  I won't lie, the A/C was rough, would have been alot easier on me had I of drank more water, dehydration isn't fun.......the Taxol is a piece of cake.........You just have to keep an optimistic attitude, it might get rough, but the outcome is worth it. Anytime you want to vent, rant, rave, cry, we're all here for you. It is scary, but we can make it together! Luv, hugs and prayers Deb
Posts.Title: First post.... KerryMac Rainenz

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 06:52AM Deb-from-Ohio wrote: I just had a lumpectomy, (stage III) and had 5 nodes removed on Tuesday Aaronali......and I'm 53. Was no problem at all....actually the anesthesia, was kind of funny. I thought they were giving me oxygen, they told me to breathe deep, turns out it was what put me to sleep! LOL.........last thing I remember.  I'm kind of sore today..have a drain in from the node removal....She also removed my port (what they used to transfuse the chemo into me)......The pain afterwards is manageable with pain pills. Having surgery is scary if you've never had it before, but if you've had a baby, this hurts way less, believe me!  Actually where she removed the port hurts the most. I haven't had any pain in my breast at all and she removed oh, between a quarter and half dollar sized amount. The node removal incision doesn't hurt that badly either........ So take a deep breath! Has anyone talked to you about Xanax or any other anti-anxiety pill? They helped me alot in the beginning........ Hugs and prayers Deb
